Introducing Zenn Bot, your smart task management assistant, designed to help you stay organised and productive.
List all completed and uncompleted task.
Add a new task to the task list.
Add a new task with a deadline to the task list.
* Deadline given cannot be in the past.
Add a new task with a start date and end date to the task list.
* The start_date and end_date format is `dd/mm/yyyy HHmm`
* start_date and end_date given cannot be in the past.
Postpone the deadline of the task by the specified number of hours.
* `snooze` can only be used for deadline and event task.
Mark a task at the given index as completed.
Mark a task at the given index as uncompleted.
Delete a task from the task list.
* `Delete` cannot be undone, you will have to add the task again.
Find tasks from the task list that contains the given word.
* Zenn Bot saves all task in a txt file after every session.
* There is no need to save update manually.
1. Ensure you have Java `17` or above installed on your computer.
3. Copy the file to the folder you want to use.
4. Open a command terminal, locate the folder of the `.jar` file.
* The main entry point of the Zenn task management application.
* Initializes the storage, task list, and user interface components,
* and runs the main command loop, allowing users to interact with the application.
* Initializes the Zenn application with necessary components:
* UI, storage, task list, command factory, and parser.
* If loading tasks from storage fails, a new task list is created.
* Runs the main command loop of the Zenn application.
* It continuously reads user input, parses the command, and executes it until the user quits the application.
* Processes user input and returns a response (for GUI integration).
return ui.showError("Unexpected Error. Please try again.");

return ui.showMessage("Bye! See you again ah!");
* Represents an abstract command in the application.
* Commands are used to perform specific actions in the application
* based on user input. Each command has associated arguments
* and must implement the {@code execute} method to define the action.
* Constructs a Command with the specified arguments.
* @param arguments The arguments passed by the user when executing the command.
* This method is abstract and serves as a blueprint for all command classes.
* @return The result of executing the command, typically a message or status.
* Creates the appropriate command based on the type of command specified by the user.
* It helps decouple the command creation logic from the main program flow.
* Constructs a CommandFactory with the given task list, storage, and user interface.
* @param tasks The task list used to manage tasks.
* @param storage The storage used to save and load tasks.
* @param ui The user interface used to interact with the user.
public CommandFactory(TaskList tasks, Storage storage, Ui ui) {
* Creates a command based on the provided command type and arguments.
* @param commandType The type of command to create (e.g., "done", "todo", "deadline").
* @param arguments The arguments passed with the command.
* @return A new {@code Command} object corresponding to the specified command type.
public Command createCommand(String commandType, String arguments) {
return new DoneCommand(arguments, tasks, storage, ui);
return new UnmarkCommand(arguments, tasks, storage, ui);
return new TodoCommand(arguments, tasks, storage, ui);
return new DeadlineCommand(arguments, tasks, storage, ui);
return new EventCommand(arguments, tasks, storage, ui);
return new DeleteCommand(arguments, tasks, storage, ui);
return new SnoozeCommand(arguments, tasks, ui, storage);
